page.title: 12Tavistock-Bedford Connection
page.content: Two gateways of the{Abbey}remain - Court Gate and Betsy Grimbal's Tower. The still tower, where the monks used to make medicines, is beside the river and there is a ruined arch from the Abbey church in the churchyard. When Henry VIII dissolved the monasteries, he gave Tavistock Abbey and all its lands to the{Russell} family, who later became the{Dukes of {Bedford.} By 1860, Francis, Duke of Bedford, rebuilt the centre of the town and built cottages, for the miners, using some of the fortune he made out of {copper mining.} Bedford Square is the centre of the town.It is there that school children dance their{May Revels}around a Maypole and perform country dances while grown-ups collect money for charity from the spectators.
